I think the actual exception should be caught and handled earlier, but I agree that we need to think about how we handle missing/deleted/renamed projects, what view the user gets of this, and what gets published to the server.

I took another look at this and from what I see there is nothing really wrong happening in the framework. There's lots of work we still have to do for renamed/deleted projects (other bugs are still open), but all it is doing in this case is asking the server type for a list of the child modules of a specific module. This is a valid method to call at any time, and it's the implementation of this server that is failing.

At some point we may still precompute the module tree or make other changes that will negate this, but I don't think it is valid to say that we can't call some methods during resource change events. Servers should catch exceptions and deal with them appropriately. If this in turn means that the list isn't correct or we need to modify the framework then please reopen, but there is nothing stopping getChildModules() from being called in other situations that would throw the same exception.

although this specific error is no longer occurring during execution (due to checks in server adapter code), it seems like it may be useful to just add logic to Server.getChildModules() to make a check for module project accessibility prior to calling getChildModules() (i.e. if IModule.getProject() == null || !IModule.getProject().isAccessible(), then just default to IModule[0] to prevent errors due to incorrect checks in server adapter implementations)
Sorry, I realize this one's a wee bit old. I've added the requested check and dropped the code to HEAD. Will release shortly.
Closing as fixed since M4.  If this was closed in error, please reopen.
